LIFE130

Overview

Overview
This is a new 7.5 credit module that will be required for all year 1 Life Sciences students. It focuses on students’ study skills while at the same time beginning to develop / raise awareness of their graduate employability skills. There are no additional resources required as this module replaces part of an existing module and will use the freed-up resources.

Rationale: The module will replace half of the current 15 cr module ‘LIFE 109 Essential Skills for the Life Sciences’ (the other half will be replaced by another new 7.5 credit module). This current module consists of two parts: communication and study skills (CSS) and quantitative skills (QS), each of these aspects contributing 50% of the module. CSS and QS are run basically completely independently, and it is difficult to envisage how this could change. The structure of each component is very different, and a different set of staff teach on them. Students find the module structure confusing, never sure whether messages and timetabled slots relate to CSS or QS. Module evaluations are not as useful as they could be because it often is unclear which module part they related to. Therefore, we propose a split into two separate modules. At the same time, we wish to update the current CSS content, learning outcomes and assessment. There are a lot of good features in the current Essential Skills modules, so we are not going to change everything. For example, the module will keep the Academic Advisor (AA) system with fortnightly small group meetings as currently take place in LIFE 109. The role of the AA remains the same as in LIFE 109, i.e. advisor plus delivery of the module. However, we found that the current module focuses too much on the assessments, presents a relatively high staff and student workload, lacks opportunities to reflect and to practice study skills, and does not make the best use of the opportunities presented by the tutorial contact time. We are, therefore, suggesting that there will be only two marked assessments. In addition, students will upload documents or complete other small tasks in a reflective Portfolio. The Portfolio will contribute a relatively small percentage to the module mark, but will have to be completed satisfactorily by the student. Fortnightly tutorials will include a discussion linked to the relevant Portfolio submission. Content and delivery of the module were designed with Curriculum 2021 in mind. The teaching on the module is research-connected, developing students’ understanding of the nature of research. Students will be active and reflective learners, engaging in enquiry-based and authentic activities. The module will also develop students’ confidence as well as digital fluency.

Because the module will affect a large number of staff and the whole year 1 student cohort, we extensively consulted both past and current students as well as programme directors of all Life Sciences programmes. In addition, we performed a staff survey aimed at all staff teaching on the module (appr. 100 staff members). The module will commence in September 2019.

External Examiner: Dr Markus Eichhorn

Other contributing Level 1 units:
Biochemistry
Cellular and Molecular Physiology
Evolution, Ecology and Behaviour
Functional and Comparative Genomics
Molecular and Clinical Pharmacology
Musculoskeletal Biology I
Musculoskeletal Biology II
Educational Aims
to provide students with study and communication skills for higher education in the Life Sciences;

to develop students’ ability to reflect on their progress and use feedback to identify opportunities for personal development;

to develop students’ appreciation of the application of these skills to future employment.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus will focus on the development of a number of skills that will support students’ learning throughout their BSc or MBiolSci programme, and will contribute to their employability thereafter. It will consolidate and build on students’ previous experience before university, which will inevitably be very diverse.

Throughout the module, students will reflect on their skills development, beginning with a skills audit and involving explicit reflection on feedback from both formative and summative assessments.

Writing skills are a focus of this module, with the two primary summative assessments being substantial pieces of written work (an essay and an experimental report). The drafting and submission of these assessments will be supported by skills development in the following areas:

•Essay writing skills
•Academic integrity
•Library skills
•Literature/internet search
•Referencing
•Experimental report components and style
•Statistical reporting

The following additional skills and opportunities will be introduced and developed:

•Designing and giving presentations
•Introduction to career development
•Placement/study abroad opportunities
•Job applications/CV writing

These underpinning and additional skills will be recorded and assessed at a competency level within the reflective portfolio, while resources and links to online material will be provided in VITAL. Submission of summative assessments will be through VITAL/Turnitin Feedback Studio. Students will be expected to maintain their portfolio, prepare for small group tutorials and to carry out independent research to develop the content of their summative assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete in preparation for the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. Tutorial topics will include e.g. research skills, writing skills, and career development. For the former, students may for example complete a formative library quiz in advance. In the tutorial, anonymous examples of good and bad resources will be evaluated and discussed. The small, pre-tutorial tasks will be part of an electronic portfolio which will only be assessed on the basis of satisfactory and timely completion (‘competency’). Although the portfolio will only contribute 20% towards the module mark, students will have to complete all portfolio tasks to a satisfactory standard in order to pass the module. There will be two marked written assessments, one in each semester. Tutorial tasks will prepare and develop students’ writing skills and students will be required to submit a formative draft for each. For the final submission, students need to explain how they implemented feedback for their draft in their submission.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy has been designed to develop active-learning and self-reflection at the start of our students’ University journeys. Individual and group feedback on approximately fortnightly authentic-assessments and self-reflections aim to support the development of study and employability skills, such as resilience and ability to recognise, and act upon, constructive feedback. A key component of the assessment is therefore the production of a skills/self-reflection portfolio. The portfolio must be passed in order to pass the module, thereby ensuring that all students have to engage with the self-reflection process. In addition to the portfolio, two written assignments are designed to be authentic and will require students to combine all the skills they have developed over the course of the module, again reducing the possibility that students can progress to the following year without having made progress in all the skills they will need for further study, placements and career development. Furthermore, the assessments will help 1st year students to start to appreciate that learning in HE is about developing the ability to utilise a range of skills and expertise e.g. literature searching, communication, and creativity to address real-life situations.

LIFE130

Overview

Overview
This is a new 7.5 credit module that will be required for all year 1 Life Sciences students. It focuses on students’ study skills while at the same time beginning to develop / raise awareness of their graduate employability skills. There are no additional resources required as this module replaces part of an existing module and will use the freed-up resources.

Rationale: The module will replace half of the current 15 cr module ‘LIFE 109 Essential Skills for the Life Sciences’ (the other half will be replaced by another new 7.5 credit module). This current module consists of two parts: communication and study skills (CSS) and quantitative skills (QS), each of these aspects contributing 50% of the module. CSS and QS are run basically completely independently, and it is difficult to envisage how this could change. The structure of each component is very different, and a different set of staff teach on them. Students find the module structure confusing, never sure whether messages and timetabled slots relate to CSS or QS. Module evaluations are not as useful as they could be because it often is unclear which module part they related to. Therefore, we propose a split into two separate modules. At the same time, we wish to update the current CSS content, learning outcomes and assessment. There are a lot of good features in the current Essential Skills modules, so we are not going to change everything. For example, the module will keep the Academic Advisor (AA) system with fortnightly small group meetings as currently take place in LIFE 109. The role of the AA remains the same as in LIFE 109, i.e. advisor plus delivery of the module. However, we found that the current module focuses too much on the assessments, presents a relatively high staff and student workload, lacks opportunities to reflect and to practice study skills, and does not make the best use of the opportunities presented by the tutorial contact time. We are, therefore, suggesting that there will be only two marked assessments. In addition, students will upload documents or complete other small tasks in a reflective Portfolio. The Portfolio will contribute a relatively small percentage to the module mark, but will have to be completed satisfactorily by the student. Fortnightly tutorials will include a discussion linked to the relevant Portfolio submission. Content and delivery of the module were designed with Curriculum 2021 in mind. The teaching on the module is research-connected, developing students’ understanding of the nature of research. Students will be active and reflective learners, engaging in enquiry-based and authentic activities. The module will also develop students’ confidence as well as digital fluency.

Because the module will affect a large number of staff and the whole year 1 student cohort, we extensively consulted both past and current students as well as programme directors of all Life Sciences programmes. In addition, we performed a staff survey aimed at all staff teaching on the module (appr. 100 staff members). The module will commence in September 2019.

External Examiner: Dr Markus Eichhorn

Other contributing Level 1 units:
Biochemistry
Cellular and Molecular Physiology
Evolution, Ecology and Behaviour
Functional and Comparative Genomics
Molecular and Clinical Pharmacology
Musculoskeletal Biology I
Musculoskeletal Biology II
Educational Aims
to provide students with study and communication skills for higher education in the Life Sciences;

to develop students’ ability to reflect on their progress and use feedback to identify opportunities for personal development;

to develop students’ appreciation of the application of these skills to future employment.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus will focus on the development of a number of skills that will support students’ learning throughout their BSc or MBiolSci programme, and will contribute to their employability thereafter. It will consolidate and build on students’ previous experience before university, which will inevitably be very diverse.

Throughout the module, students will reflect on their skills development, beginning with a skills audit and involving explicit reflection on feedback from both formative and summative assessments.

Writing skills are a focus of this module, with the two primary summative assessments being substantial pieces of written work (an essay and an experimental report). The drafting and submission of these assessments will be supported by skills development in the following areas:

•Essay writing skills
•Academic integrity
•Library skills
•Literature/internet search
•Referencing
•Experimental report components and style
•Statistical reporting

The following additional skills and opportunities will be introduced and developed:

•Designing and giving presentations
•Introduction to career development
•Placement/study abroad opportunities
•Job applications/CV writing

These underpinning and additional skills will be recorded and assessed at a competency level within the reflective portfolio, while resources and links to online material will be provided in VITAL. Submission of summative assessments will be through VITAL/Turnitin Feedback Studio. Students will be expected to maintain their portfolio, prepare for small group tutorials and to carry out independent research to develop the content of their summative assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete in preparation for the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. Tutorial topics will include e.g. research skills, writing skills, and career development. For the former, students may for example complete a formative library quiz in advance. In the tutorial, anonymous examples of good and bad resources will be evaluated and discussed. The small, pre-tutorial tasks will be part of an electronic portfolio which will only be assessed on the basis of satisfactory and timely completion (‘competency’). Although the portfolio will only contribute 20% towards the module mark, students will have to complete all portfolio tasks to a satisfactory standard in order to pass the module. There will be two marked written assessments, one in each semester. Tutorial tasks will prepare and develop students’ writing skills and students will be required to submit a formative draft for each. For the final submission, students need to explain how they implemented feedback for their draft in their submission.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy has been designed to develop active-learning and self-reflection at the start of our students’ University journeys. Individual and group feedback on approximately fortnightly authentic-assessments and self-reflections aim to support the development of study and employability skills, such as resilience and ability to recognise, and act upon, constructive feedback. A key component of the assessment is therefore the production of a skills/self-reflection portfolio. The portfolio must be passed in order to pass the module, thereby ensuring that all students have to engage with the self-reflection process. In addition to the portfolio, two written assignments are designed to be authentic and will require students to combine all the skills they have developed over the course of the module, again reducing the possibility that students can progress to the following year without having made progress in all the skills they will need for further study, placements and career development. Furthermore, the assessments will help 1st year students to start to appreciate that learning in HE is about developing the ability to utilise a range of skills and expertise e.g. literature searching, communication, and creativity to address real-life situations.

LIFE130

Overview

Overview
This is a new 7.5 credit module that will be required for all year 1 Life Sciences students. It focuses on students’ study skills while at the same time beginning to develop / raise awareness of their graduate employability skills. There are no additional resources required as this module replaces part of an existing module and will use the freed-up resources.

Rationale: The module will replace half of the current 15 cr module ‘LIFE 109 Essential Skills for the Life Sciences’ (the other half will be replaced by another new 7.5 credit module). This current module consists of two parts: communication and study skills (CSS) and quantitative skills (QS), each of these aspects contributing 50% of the module. CSS and QS are run basically completely independently, and it is difficult to envisage how this could change. The structure of each component is very different, and a different set of staff teach on them. Students find the module structure confusing, never sure whether messages and timetabled slots relate to CSS or QS. Module evaluations are not as useful as they could be because it often is unclear which module part they related to. Therefore, we propose a split into two separate modules. At the same time, we wish to update the current CSS content, learning outcomes and assessment. There are a lot of good features in the current Essential Skills modules, so we are not going to change everything. For example, the module will keep the Academic Advisor (AA) system with fortnightly small group meetings as currently take place in LIFE 109. The role of the AA remains the same as in LIFE 109, i.e. advisor plus delivery of the module. However, we found that the current module focuses too much on the assessments, presents a relatively high staff and student workload, lacks opportunities to reflect and to practice study skills, and does not make the best use of the opportunities presented by the tutorial contact time. We are, therefore, suggesting that there will be only two marked assessments. In addition, students will upload documents or complete other small tasks in a reflective Portfolio. The Portfolio will contribute a relatively small percentage to the module mark, but will have to be completed satisfactorily by the student. Fortnightly tutorials will include a discussion linked to the relevant Portfolio submission. Content and delivery of the module were designed with Curriculum 2021 in mind. The teaching on the module is research-connected, developing students’ understanding of the nature of research. Students will be active and reflective learners, engaging in enquiry-based and authentic activities. The module will also develop students’ confidence as well as digital fluency.

Because the module will affect a large number of staff and the whole year 1 student cohort, we extensively consulted both past and current students as well as programme directors of all Life Sciences programmes. In addition, we performed a staff survey aimed at all staff teaching on the module (appr. 100 staff members). The module will commence in September 2019.

External Examiner: Dr Markus Eichhorn

Other contributing Level 1 units:
Biochemistry
Cellular and Molecular Physiology
Evolution, Ecology and Behaviour
Functional and Comparative Genomics
Molecular and Clinical Pharmacology
Musculoskeletal Biology I
Musculoskeletal Biology II
Educational Aims
to provide students with study and communication skills for higher education in the Life Sciences;

to develop students’ ability to reflect on their progress and use feedback to identify opportunities for personal development;

to develop students’ appreciation of the application of these skills to future employment.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus will focus on the development of a number of skills that will support students’ learning throughout their BSc or MBiolSci programme, and will contribute to their employability thereafter. It will consolidate and build on students’ previous experience before university, which will inevitably be very diverse.

Throughout the module, students will reflect on their skills development, beginning with a skills audit and involving explicit reflection on feedback from both formative and summative assessments.

Writing skills are a focus of this module, with the two primary summative assessments being substantial pieces of written work (an essay and an experimental report). The drafting and submission of these assessments will be supported by skills development in the following areas:

•Essay writing skills
•Academic integrity
•Library skills
•Literature/internet search
•Referencing
•Experimental report components and style
•Statistical reporting

The following additional skills and opportunities will be introduced and developed:

•Designing and giving presentations
•Introduction to career development
•Placement/study abroad opportunities
•Job applications/CV writing

These underpinning and additional skills will be recorded and assessed at a competency level within the reflective portfolio, while resources and links to online material will be provided in VITAL. Submission of summative assessments will be through VITAL/Turnitin Feedback Studio. Students will be expected to maintain their portfolio, prepare for small group tutorials and to carry out independent research to develop the content of their summative assessments.
Teaching and Learning Methods
The module is based on fortnightly small-group tutorials with an Academic Advisor. Each tutorial will have a topic that relates to a small task which students need to complete in preparation for the tutorial. The topics will be introduced within plenary lectures. Tutorial topics will include e.g. research skills, writing skills, and career development. For the former, students may for example complete a formative library quiz in advance. In the tutorial, anonymous examples of good and bad resources will be evaluated and discussed. The small, pre-tutorial tasks will be part of an electronic portfolio which will only be assessed on the basis of satisfactory and timely completion (‘competency’). Although the portfolio will only contribute 20% towards the module mark, students will have to complete all portfolio tasks to a satisfactory standard in order to pass the module. There will be two marked written assessments, one in each semester. Tutorial tasks will prepare and develop students’ writing skills and students will be required to submit a formative draft for each. For the final submission, students need to explain how they implemented feedback for their draft in their submission.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy has been designed to develop active-learning and self-reflection at the start of our students’ University journeys. Individual and group feedback on approximately fortnightly authentic-assessments and self-reflections aim to support the development of study and employability skills, such as resilience and ability to recognise, and act upon, constructive feedback. A key component of the assessment is therefore the production of a skills/self-reflection portfolio. The portfolio must be passed in order to pass the module, thereby ensuring that all students have to engage with the self-reflection process. In addition to the portfolio, two written assignments are designed to be authentic and will require students to combine all the skills they have developed over the course of the module, again reducing the possibility that students can progress to the following year without having made progress in all the skills they will need for further study, placements and career development. Furthermore, the assessments will help 1st year students to start to appreciate that learning in HE is about developing the ability to utilise a range of skills and expertise e.g. literature searching, communication, and creativity to address real-life situations.
